Asynchronous Server Gateway Interface (ASGI)¶

  • Introduction

  • Classes

    • Request

    • Response

    • Resource

    • Resource controller

  • Starlette

    • Implemented classes

  • Implementing Starlette

Introduction¶

The ASGI module consists of the following classes:

  1. Request

    A request object holds all information about the client requesting a resource.

  2. Response

    A response contains all data which the user will receive.

  3. Resource

    A resource executes the action which the user requests.

  4. ResourceController

    A resource controller manages the database connection and routes the user to the correct resource.

When the server receives a request, the information contained by the request will be converted into a RequestInterface by a ResourceControllerInterface, which then passes the request further to a ResourceInterface. The resource will execute the requested actions and return a ResponseInterface which in the end will be outputted by the ResourceController.

Classes¶

Request¶

class tedious.asgi.request_interface.RequestInterface[source]¶

The request interface is an abstract class which will be used by ResourceInterface instances to extract all necessary information about who the requester is and what he wants to do.

property client¶

The client identifies the users ip address and port.

Returns

Tuple(client ip, client port)

property cookies¶

Returns dict of requesters cookies.

async get_body_bytes() → bytes[source]¶

Reads the requests body as bytes. :returns: Body as bytes

async get_body_json() → dict[source]¶

Ready the requests body and decodes it as json.

Returns

Body decoded as dict.

get_header(key, default=None)[source]¶

Retrieve single header value.

Returns

Header value as str.

get_param(key, default=None)[source]¶

Retrieve single parameter value. :returns: Parameter value as str.

property method¶

Identifies the HTTP methods used by the requester.

Returns

A static attribute of Methods

property requester¶

The requester identifies the signed in user.

Returns

If the user is signed in an instance of Requester, else None

property url¶

The complete url accessed by the user.

Returns

URL as str.

Response¶

class tedious.asgi.response_interface.ResponseInterface(body=None, headers=None, status_code=200, media_type=None)[source]¶

The response interface simply tells the ResourceControllerInterface what it would like to return and with what HTTP response headers.

Resource¶

class tedious.asgi.resource_interface.ResourceInterface[source]¶

The resource interface executes the requested actions.

Called on HTTP DELETE requests.

  • logger (Logger) – Logger used to track activity of requester.

async on_request(request: tedious.asgi.request_interface.RequestInterface, connection: tedious.sql.interface.SQLConnectionInterface, logger: tedious.logger.Logger, **kwargs) → tedious.asgi.response_interface.ResponseInterface[source]¶
Routes request according to HTTP method to either on_get,

on_post, on_put, on_delete

Parameters

  • request (RequestInterface) – The request containing all information about the requester and what he would like to do.

  • connection (SQLConnectionInterface) – Short lived connection to database.

  • logger (Logger) – Logger used to track activity of requester.

  • **kwargs – Additional instances which will be passed along to the members mentioned above.

Returns

Instance of type ResponseInterface

raise_bad_request(msg='404 Bad Request')[source]¶

Raises HTTPBadRequest.

raise_forbidden(msg='403 Forbidden')[source]¶

Raises HTTPForbidden.

raise_not_found(msg='404 Not Found')[source]¶

Raises HTTPNotFound.

Resource controller¶

class tedious.asgi.resource_controller_interface.ResourceControllerInterface[source]¶

The resource controller controls a request from start to finish. It converts requests into instances of RequestInterface and returns instances of ResourceInterface back to the requester.

async handle(**kwargs) → tedious.asgi.response_interface.ResponseInterface[source]¶

This method should receive requests, convert them to RequestInterface and run route request to tedious.asgi.resource_interface.ResourceInterface.on_request and return a ResourceInterface.

Returns

ResourceInterface

async handle_exceptions(exception) → tedious.asgi.response_interface.ResponseInterface[source]¶

Converts exception into ResourceInterface.

Returns

ResourceInterface

async run_safe(func, *args, **kwargs) → tedious.asgi.response_interface.ResponseInterface[source]¶

This method encapsulates all methods so that exceptions can be easily caught and handled.

Parameters

  • func – Coroutine to be awaited.

  • *args – Positional arguments to be passed along to func.

  • **kwargs – Named arguments to be passed along to func.

Returns

ResourceInterface returned by func.

Starlette¶

Tedious offers a complete implementation of Starlette.

Implemented classes¶

This class makes Starlette requests readable by the tedious framework. .. Starlette https://www.starlette.io/requests/

class tedious.asgi.starlette.ResourceController(database: tedious.sql.interface.SQLInterface)[source]¶

Implementation of ResourceControllerInterface for Starlette.

async handle(request: starlette.requests.Request, resource: tedious.asgi.resource_interface.ResourceInterface, **kwargs) → starlette.responses.Response[source]¶
Converts the StarletteRequest into a RequestInterface, passes this new object to the resource and converts the returned response into

a Starlette acceptable response.

Parameters

  • request – Starlette request passed by route.

  • resource (ResourceInterface) – Instance of resource which will be tasked with handling request.

  • **kwargs – Named parameters to be passed to handle_request

async handle_exceptions(exception)[source]¶

Handles various exceptions and converts them into ResponseInterface

Implementing Starlette¶

This example shows how you would implement the AuthResource class to allow users to sign in via a POST request on /login.

import tedious.config
from tedious.asgi.starlette import ResourceController, StarletteApp
from tedious.res import AuthResource
from tedious.sql.postgres import PostgreSQLDatabase
from starlette.routing import Route

tedious.config.load_config('config.ini')

controller = ResourceController(PostgreSQLDatabase(**tedious.config.CONFIG["DB_CREDENTIALS"]))


async def login(request):
    return await controller.handle(request, AuthResource())


app = StarletteApp(controller, [Route('/login', login, methods=["POST", "PUT", "DELETE"])]).app

Now you could POST a request containing the following JSON body onto /login and receive an access and refresh token, given that the user has been registered with the tedious.auth.Auth.register member.

{
    "username": "test",
    "password": "12345678
}

If you would like to create your own resources, create a class like the following:

from tedious.sql.interface import SQLConnectionInterface
from tedious.asgi.response_interface import PlainTextResponse
from tedious.asgi.request_interface import RequestInterface
from tedious.logger import Logger

class HelloWorldResource(ResourceInterface):

   async def on_get(self, request: RequestInterface, connection: SQLConnectionInterface, logger: Logger) -> ResponseInterface:

        if request.requester is None:
            # User is not signed in
            return PlainTextResponse('Hello World!')
        else:
            # user is signed in
            return PlainTextResponse('Hello {}!'.format(request.requester.uuid))

and then link the new resource by creating a route which finally has to be added to the StarletteApp routes.

async def hello_world(request):
    return await controller.handle(request, HelloWorldResource())

app = StarletteApp(controller, [Route('/login', login, methods=["POST", "PUT", "DELETE"]),
       Route('/hello_world', hello_world, methods=["GET"])]).app

To sign in a user, don’t forget to add the Authorization HTTP header accompanied by a bearer token.

Tedious
